q: In which year did the Norman conquest begin with the Battle of Hastings?
explain: William of Normandy defeated King Harold in 1066.

q: What are the two Houses of the UK Parliament?
explain: Parliament comprises the House of Commons and the House of Lords.

q: Which is a responsibility of all UK residents?
options: Serve on a jury every year
explain: Obeying the law is required; the others are optional.

q: Which of the following is NOT one of the four nations of the UK?
explain: The UK is England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

q: St Andrew’s Day is the national day of which UK nation?
explain: Celebrated on 30 November in Scotland.

q: How many jurors usually serve on a criminal jury in England and Wales?
explain: Typically 12 jurors.

q: What is the Magna Carta best known for?
options: Limiting the powers of the monarch
explain: Signed in 1215; established the principle that the king is subject to the law.

q: What is the minimum age to vote in UK general elections?
explain: 18 for UK general elections.

q: Which of the following requires a TV licence in the UK?
options: Only watching on a TV set
Watching or recording live TV on any device
explain: Live TV (any device) or BBC iPlayer requires a licence.

q: What is the capital city of Northern Ireland?
explain: Belfast is the capital.

q: What is the usual age range for jury service eligibility in England and Wales?
explain: Generally 18–70 (some extensions/changes may apply by jurisdiction).

q: Who invites the leader of the majority party in the Commons to become Prime Minister?
explain: The Monarch appoints the Prime Minister.

q: In which year did the ‘Glorious Revolution’ take place?
explain: 1688: William of Orange took the throne; a key step toward constitutional monarchy.

q: The title ‘Poet Laureate’ is associated with which of the following?
explain: It’s a royal appointment for a distinguished poet.

q: Approximately how many MPs sit in the House of Commons?
explain: There are currently 650 seats (this can change with boundary reviews).

q: What is the longest river in the UK?
explain: The Severn is the longest; the Thames is the longest entirely in England.

q: Small claims cases in England & Wales are usually heard in which court?
explain: The small claims track is part of the County Court system.

q: Which English king is associated with the establishment of the Church of England separate from Rome?
explain: Henry VIII broke with Rome in the 16th century.

q: Which people first built towns and roads extensively in Britain?
explain: The Romans occupied much of Britain from AD 43 and built roads and towns.

q: Boudicca led a famous revolt against which empire?
explain: Boudicca was a Celtic queen who rebelled against Roman rule in AD 60–61.

q: Which monarch established the Church of England separate from Rome?
explain: Henry VIII broke with the Roman Catholic Church in the 16th century.

q: What event is marked by Bonfire Night on 5 November?
explain: It marks the failure of the 1605 Gunpowder Plot to blow up Parliament.

q: In which year was the National Health Service (NHS) founded?
explain: The NHS began in 1948, providing healthcare free at the point of use.

q: Who leads the UK government?
explain: The Prime Minister leads the government and appoints ministers.

q: A political party’s promises for government are usually set out in what?
explain: Parties publish manifestos during elections to outline their policies.

q: Which of the following is a legal responsibility for residents?
options: To serve in the armed forces
explain: Paying taxes and obeying the law are fundamental civic duties.

q: What number should you dial in the UK to reach the emergency services?
explain: 999 and 112 both connect to emergency services in the UK.

q: Which pairing of nation and capital is correct?
explain: Belfast is the capital of Northern Ireland.

q: What is the highest mountain in the UK?
explain: Ben Nevis, in Scotland, is the highest.

q: William Shakespeare is known for writing which of the following?
explain: Shakespeare wrote plays and poetry in the late 16th and early 17th centuries.

q: Wimbledon is a major tournament in which sport?
explain: Wimbledon is the world’s oldest tennis tournament.

q: The 1689 Bill of Rights limited the powers of the monarch and confirmed which principle?
explain: It established key constitutional principles and strengthened Parliament.

q: The Acts of Union 1707 created which political entity?
options: The United Kingdom of Great Britain
The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland
explain: England (including Wales) and Scotland formed Great Britain in 1707.

q: At which battle in 1815 was Napoleon finally defeated by British-led forces?
explain: The Duke of Wellington defeated Napoleon at Waterloo in 1815.

q: What is the Cabinet?
options: Senior ministers chosen by the PM
The steering committee of the civil service
explain: The Cabinet comprises senior government ministers selected by the Prime Minister.

q: Which services are commonly provided by local councils?
explain: Local authorities handle services like waste, planning, and libraries.

q: Who is generally regarded as Britain’s first Prime Minister?
explain: Robert Walpole served as First Lord of the Treasury from 1721.

q: What might happen if you are called for jury service?
options: It’s a civic duty and you may have to attend
You can choose to do it every year
explain: Jury service is a civic responsibility for eligible people.

q: Which body can help resolve employment disputes and advise on rights at work?
explain: Citizens Advice offers free, impartial guidance on many legal and consumer issues.

q: The Giant’s Causeway is located in which part of the UK?
explain: It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site on the north coast of Northern Ireland.

q: Which is the largest lake by area in the UK?
explain: Lough Neagh in Northern Ireland is the largest by surface area.

q: Which author wrote “Pride and Prejudice”?
explain: Jane Austen published it in 1813.

q: Sir Tim Berners-Lee is best known for which achievement?
explain: He invented the World Wide Web while working at CERN.

q: In which year did the ‘Glorious Revolution’ occur?
explain: In 1688 William of Orange took the throne, advancing constitutional monarchy.

q: What did the Reform Act of 1832 primarily change?
options: Extended the franchise and reformed constituencies
explain: It widened (though still limited) voting rights and removed ‘rotten boroughs’.

q: Which statement best describes the ‘rule of law’ in the UK?
options: The government can overrule courts at will
Everyone, including the government, is subject to the law
Only Parliament is above the law
explain: No one is above the law; laws are applied equally.

q: What is ‘common law’?
options: Laws made only by the EU
Law developed by judges through decisions
explain: Common law evolves through court judgments as well as statutes passed by Parliament.

q: Which activities typically require a licence or permission in the UK?
options: Driving a car on public roads
explain: Driving requires a licence and adherence to road laws.

q: Serious criminal cases in England and Wales are tried in which court?
explain: Serious offences are heard in the Crown Court before a judge and jury.

q: Which crosses are combined in the Union Flag (Union Jack)?
options: St George, St Andrew, St Patrick
St David, St George, St Andrew
St Patrick, St David, St George
St Andrew, St David, St Michael
explain: It combines the crosses of the patron saints of England, Scotland and Ireland (not Wales).

q: Which of the following are Crown Dependencies and not part of the UK?
options: Isle of Man and Channel Islands
explain: The Isle of Man and the Channel Islands are self-governing Crown Dependencies.

q: Match the patron saints to their nations: St George, St Andrew, St David, St Patrick.
explain: St George (England), St Andrew (Scotland), St David (Wales), St Patrick (Northern Ireland).

q: Which set correctly lists national emblems/flowers?
explain: These are the commonly recognised national emblems.
